quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The team that works in the most futuristic way is the Claude Code team. They're using Claude Code to build Claude Code in a very self-improving kind of way.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for AI-native product development: use your own AI tooling to iteratively improve itself.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We really rapidly became bottlenecked on other things like our merge queue. We had to completely re-architect it because so much more code was being written and so many more pull requests were being submitted.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Actionable operational lesson: when AI accelerates coding, engineering throughput shifts bottlenecks to review/merge infrastructure that must be redesigned.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Over half of our pull requests are Claude Code generated. Probably at this point it's probably over 70% that it just completely blew out the expectations of it.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A specific data point showing how quickly AI-generated code can dominate PR volume, impacting team processes and tooling needs.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I think there's room for several generationally important companies to be built in AI right now. How do we figure out what we want to be when we grow up versus what we currently aren't or wish that we were or see other players in the space being?
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A strategic framing for product leaders: define identity and differentiation in a multi-winner market rather than copying the current leader.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I had this notion coming in like, "Yes, these models are great, but are they able to have an independent opinion?" And it's actually really flipped for me only in the last month.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A counterintuitive update on model capabilities that challenges assumptions about whether AI can form independent viewpoints.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And as an end-end platform, Productboard seamlessly supports all stages of the product development lifecycle.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Highlights an end-to-end lifecycle approach and the value of a single platform spanning discovery through delivery.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: From gathering customer insights to planning a roadmap, to aligning stakeholders, to earning customer buy-in, all with a single source of truth.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A practical product operating model: connect insights → roadmap → alignment → buy-in using one canonical system.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With Productboard Pulse, a new voice of customer solution built-in intelligence helps you analyze trends across all of your feedback and then dive deeper by asking AI your follow-up questions.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Actionable workflow for VoC: trend analysis across feedback plus iterative AI follow-up to deepen understanding.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Last year, 1.3% of the global GDP flowed through Stripe.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A concrete scale data point that signals Stripe’s reach and reliability for high-volume payments.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: For example, Hertz boosted its online payment authorization rates by 4% after migrating to Stripe.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Specific outcome metric showing how payments infrastructure changes can directly improve conversion/acceptance rates.

quotes.topic_title: What Mike changed his mind about AI
quotes.text: Two things. One is like a pace and timeline question. The other one is a capability question.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A simple, reusable framework for evaluating AI progress: separate beliefs about capability from beliefs about timelines.

quotes.topic_title: What Mike changed his mind about AI
quotes.text: And it's actually really flipped for me only in the last month and only with Opus 4 where my go-to product strategy partner is Claude.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A concrete practitioner workflow shift: using a frontier model as a default strategy partner, not just a writing/coding tool.

quotes.topic_title: What Mike changed his mind about AI
quotes.text: And Opus 4, I was working on some strategy for our second half of the year was the first one.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A specific example of where he first saw the model become meaningfully useful for real planning work (H2 strategy).

quotes.topic_title: What Mike changed his mind about AI
quotes.text: He's like, "I think we'll be at 90% by the end of 2025 or something like that." And sure enough, we're at about 72 now with the new models and we're at 50% when he made that prediction.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A data-backed illustration of rapid benchmark progress that supports taking aggressive AI timelines more seriously.

quotes.topic_title: What Mike changed his mind about AI
quotes.text: And I had the very bizarre experience of I had two tabs open, it was AI 2027 and my product strategy. And it was this moment where I'm like, "Wait, am I the character in the story? How much is this converging?"
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A memorable mental check for practitioners: compare your roadmap against plausible near-term AI scenarios to see where they’re converging.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding scary AI futures and why Anthropic
quotes.text: Where can I maximally apply my time to nudge things towards going well?
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A practical prioritization question for choosing where to work or what to build to have the most positive leverage on AI outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding scary AI futures and why Anthropic
quotes.text: And so I think coming to an agreement and a shared framework and understanding of what does going well look like?
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Highlights the need to explicitly define success criteria for “good” AI futures before optimizing products or research.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding scary AI futures and why Anthropic
quotes.text: What is the kind of human AI relationship that we want?
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Reframes AI safety and progress around designing the desired human–AI relationship, not just model capability.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding scary AI futures and why Anthropic
quotes.text: How will we know along the way? What do we need to build and develop and research along the way?
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Encourages setting up ongoing measurement and milestones, then aligning build/research plans to those checkpoints.

quotes.topic_title: Avoiding scary AI futures and why Anthropic
quotes.text: And some of those are product questions and some of those are research and interpretability questions,
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A useful methodology reminder that steering AI outcomes requires coordinated product, research, and interpretability work—not just one discipline.

quotes.topic_title: Raising kids in an AI world
quotes.text: And we started changing, "Well, how would we find out?" And the answer can't just be we'll ask Claude, all right, well, we could do this experiment, we could have this thing.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A practical parenting (and learning) shift from outsourcing answers to AI toward building a repeatable discovery process.

quotes.topic_title: Raising kids in an AI world
quotes.text: So I think nurturing curiosity and still having a sense of, I don't know, the scientific process sounds grandiose to instill in a 6-year-old, but that process of discovery and asking questions and then systematically working right through, I think will still be important.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A methodology for staying capable in an AI-rich world: preserve the habits of inquiry and systematic reasoning.

quotes.topic_title: Raising kids in an AI world
quotes.text: You can ask Claude, but I know I'm right.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A memorable example of maintaining confidence and independent judgment even when AI is available.

quotes.topic_title: Raising kids in an AI world
quotes.text: I want that kind of level of not just delegating all of your cognition to the AI because it won't always get it right. And also it kind of short circuits any kind of independent thought.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that heavy AI reliance can reduce thinking quality and autonomy, even when it boosts speed.

quotes.topic_title: Raising kids in an AI world
quotes.text: So the skill of asking questions, inquiry and independent thinking, I think those are all the pieces.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A concise skills framework practitioners can apply when designing education, training, or team norms around AI.

quotes.topic_title: When 90% of code is AI-written
quotes.text: my favorite things that happen now are some nice PMs that have an idea that they want to express or designers that have an idea they want to express will use Claude and maybe even Artifacts to put together an actual functional demo.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Shows a concrete, repeatable workflow shift: PMs/designers can prototype functional demos directly with AI to make ideas tangible earlier.

quotes.topic_title: When 90% of code is AI-written
quotes.text: We really rapidly became bottlenecked on other things like our merge queue, which is the get in line to get your change accepted by the system that then deploys into production. We had to completely re-architect it because so much more code was being written and so many more pull requests were being submitted that it just completely blew out the expectations of it.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A specific example of a new operational constraint when AI accelerates coding: shipping infrastructure (merge/deploy flow) becomes the limiting factor.

quotes.topic_title: When 90% of code is AI-written
quotes.text: I've just found all these new bottlenecks in our system, there's an upstream bottleneck, which is decision making and alignment.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing: when code is cheap, the critical path shifts to strategy, alignment, and coordination rather than implementation.

quotes.topic_title: When 90% of code is AI-written
quotes.text: A lot of things that I'm thinking about right now is how do I provide the minimum viable strategy to let people feel empowered to go run and type and build and explore at the edge of model capabilities.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Introduces a practical leadership heuristic (“minimum viable strategy”) for enabling fast, decentralized building without losing coherence.

quotes.topic_title: When 90% of code is AI-written
quotes.text: So can you use a different Claude to review it and then do the human almost acceptance testing more than trying to review line by line.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A concrete process change for AI-generated code: shift humans from line-by-line review to acceptance testing, with AI reviewing AI.

quotes.topic_title: Claude Code as self-improving “patient zero”
quotes.text: At this point, I would be shocked if it wasn't 95% plus.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A striking data point suggesting AI can generate the vast majority of a production codebase when the team fully adopts AI-native workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Claude Code as self-improving “patient zero”
quotes.text: It's actually our largest TypeScript project. Most of the rest of Anthropic is written in Python, some Go, some Rust now, but we're not like a TypeScript shop.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Shows how AI assistance can make it viable to take on a major project in a language that isn’t the organization’s default strength.

quotes.topic_title: Claude Code as self-improving “patient zero”
quotes.text: And so I saw a great comment yesterday in our Slack where somebody had this thing that was driving them crazy about Claude Code and they're like, "Well, I don't know any TypeScript, I'm just going to talk to Claude about it and do it."
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A concrete example of using AI to bypass skill gaps and unblock work without waiting for specialists.

quotes.topic_title: Claude Code as self-improving “patient zero”
quotes.text: And they went from that to pull requests in an hour and solve their problem and they submitted a pull request and that breaking down the barriers.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Illustrates a practical outcome—rapid PR creation—that teams can aim for by integrating AI into day-to-day development.

quotes.topic_title: Claude Code as self-improving “patient zero”
quotes.text: One, it changes your barrier to entry for any kind of newcomer to the project.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A reusable mental model: AI lowers onboarding friction, enabling broader contribution beyond the core team.

quotes.topic_title: Speeding upstream work: feedback-to-PR loops and MCP
quotes.text: We think a lot about the virtual collaborator on topic and one of the ways in which I think that can show up is, "Hey, I'm in the Discord, the Claude Anthropic Discord, I'm in the user Fora, I'm on X and I'm reading things and here's what's emergent."
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A concrete mental model for using AI as a continuous “virtual collaborator” that synthesizes community feedback into emergent themes.

quotes.topic_title: Speeding upstream work: feedback-to-PR loops and MCP
quotes.text: Step two, which the models probably can do today, which have to wire them up to do it is and not only are the problems here's how I think you might be able to solve them. And then taking that through to, and I put together a pull request to solve this thing that I'm seeing feels very achievable this year than stringing those things together and we're limited more.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: An actionable workflow: go from problem detection → proposed solution → auto-generated PR, emphasizing that integration is the main blocker.

quotes.topic_title: Speeding upstream work: feedback-to-PR loops and MCP
quotes.text: This is why MCP is exciting to me. We're limited more around making sure the context flows through all of that so we have the right access to those things more than the model's capability to reason and propose.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A counterintuitive bottleneck callout: context plumbing and access matter more than model reasoning for speeding feedback-to-code loops.

quotes.topic_title: Speeding upstream work: feedback-to-PR loops and MCP
quotes.text: That feedback was in the RUX channel. I would've loved an hour later for a plot to be like, "Hey, if we do want to change it back, here's the PR to do it." And by the way, eventually, and then I'm going to spin up an A/B test to see if this changes metrics and then we'll see how it looks in a week.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A vivid example of compressing the feedback-to-PR-to-experiment loop into hours, not weeks, with automated PRs and A/B tests.

quotes.topic_title: Speeding upstream work: feedback-to-PR loops and MCP
quotes.text: If you told me that about a year and a half ago going to be like, "Ah, yeah, maybe like 27, maybe 26." But it really feels just at the tip of capabilities right now.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A timeline data point showing how quickly feasibility has shifted—what felt years away now feels immediately achievable.

quotes.topic_title: PM leverage comes from working with researchers
quotes.text: It's continued to be true. And in fact I think that if the proportion was already skewing towards having more of that embedding, I've just become more and more convinced. I didn't feel as strongly about it during the summit and now I feel really strongly about it.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Reinforces (and strengthens) the counterintuitive claim that PM leverage in AI products increasingly comes from embedding with research rather than focusing primarily on UX polish.

quotes.topic_title: PM leverage comes from working with researchers
quotes.text: If we're shipping things that could have been built by anybody just using our models off the shelf, there's great stuff to be built by using our models off the shelf by the way, don't get me wrong, but where we should play and what we can do uniquely should be stuff that's really at that magic intersection between the two, right?
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A positioning framework: differentiate by building at the intersection of product and model/post-training, not by shipping what any team can do with off-the-shelf models.

quotes.topic_title: PM leverage comes from working with researchers
quotes.text: Artifacts may a great example and if you play with Artifacts with Claude 4, that's an actually really interesting example where we took somebody from our, we have Claude code skills, which is a team that really is doing the post-training around teaching Claude some of these really specific skills and we paired it with some product people and then together we revamped how this looks in the product today and what Claude can do way better than just like, "Yeah, we just used the model and we prompted a little bit."
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Concrete example of a high-leverage operating model: pairing post-training specialists with product to create a differentiated experience beyond prompting.

quotes.topic_title: PM leverage comes from working with researchers
quotes.text: That's just not enough. We need to be in that fine-tuning process.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Direct, actionable guidance for AI product teams: move beyond prompting and get involved in post-training/fine-tuning to unlock real differentiation.

quotes.topic_title: PM leverage comes from working with researchers
quotes.text: It's more like we are in the post-training conversations around how these things should work and then we are in the building process and we're feeding those things back and looping them back.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Describes a methodology shift: product work becomes an iterative loop with post-training and build feedback, not a linear “model then product” handoff.

quotes.topic_title: Where product value remains in the AI era
quotes.text: I think there's still a lot of value in two things. One is making this all comprehensible.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Frames a core, enduring product responsibility in the AI era: translating powerful capabilities into something people can actually understand and use.

quotes.topic_title: Where product value remains in the AI era
quotes.text: What's still the difference between somebody who's really adept at using these tools in their work and most people is huge.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Highlights a practical adoption gap teams can target with onboarding, education, UX, and workflow design.

quotes.topic_title: Where product value remains in the AI era
quotes.text: But I still think that's a necessary part of good product development, which is the capabilities are there and even if Claude can create products from scratch, what are you building and how do you make it Comprehensible?
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Emphasizes that even with AI building capabilities, product differentiation remains in choosing what to build and making it legible to humans.

quotes.topic_title: Where product value remains in the AI era
quotes.text: Two is, and this straight to call back to another one of your guests, strategy, how we win, where we'll play, figuring out where exactly you're going to want to, of all the things that you could be spending your time or your tokens or your computation on what you want to actually go and do.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Provides a concrete strategy lens for AI products: allocate scarce resources (time/tokens/compute) toward a clear “where to play/how to win.”

quotes.topic_title: Where product value remains in the AI era
quotes.text: We call it overhang. The delta between what the models and the products can do and how they're being used on a daily basis. Huge overhang.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Names a useful product diagnosis (“overhang”) that teams can measure and reduce by revealing use cases and enabling behavior change.

quotes.topic_title: Prompting tactics and Anthropic’s prompt improver
quotes.text: But I will do small things like in Claude Code and we actually do react to this very literally, but I always ask it to, if I wanted to use more reasoning, think hard and it'll use a different flow and I usually start with that.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A simple, repeatable prompt tweak (“think hard”) that reliably shifts the model into a more reasoning-heavy mode.

quotes.topic_title: Prompting tactics and Anthropic’s prompt improver
quotes.text: And so with Claude sometimes I'm like, "Be brutal, Claude, roast me. Tell me what's wrong with this strategy."
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A counterintuitive tactic: explicitly request harsh critique to overcome overly polite feedback and surface real flaws.

quotes.topic_title: Prompting tactics and Anthropic’s prompt improver
quotes.text: So if you go to our console, our work bench, we have this thing called the prompt improver where you describe the problem and you give it examples and Claude itself will agentically create and then iterate on a prompt for you.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for practitioners: use an iterative, example-driven “prompt improver” workflow rather than one-shot prompting.

quotes.topic_title: Prompting tactics and Anthropic’s prompt improver
quotes.text: It'll insert XML tags which no human is going to think to do ahead of time.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A specific example of how automated prompt optimization can outperform human intuition via structured formatting.

quotes.topic_title: Prompting tactics and Anthropic’s prompt improver
quotes.text: So that's another one is watch our prompt improver and then note that Claude itself is a very good prompter of Claude.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A memorable meta-lesson: delegate prompt design to the model itself to get better prompts than you’d write manually.

quotes.topic_title: Rick Rubin collaboration and “vibe coding”
quotes.text: The core piece of advice you shared early is just do the opposite of what you would naturally do. So if you're trying to be nice, just be brutal, be very honest and frank with me.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive prompting tactic: invert your default communication style to get more useful feedback from an AI.

quotes.topic_title: Rick Rubin collaboration and “vibe coding”
quotes.text: Exactly. I find that works quite well. What are the thought patterns that I've fallen into that you want to break me out of?
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A practical prompt pattern for using AI to identify and disrupt personal cognitive ruts.

quotes.topic_title: Rick Rubin collaboration and “vibe coding”
quotes.text: But yeah, this sort of like med meditation is probably the right word. Meditation on creativity, working alongside AI coupled with this really rich, interesting visualizations.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Frames “vibe coding” as a methodology: treat AI collaboration as a reflective creative practice, not just a productivity tool.

quotes.topic_title: Rick Rubin collaboration and “vibe coding”
quotes.text: But it's one of those things where internally they're like, "Oh yeah, and we're doing this Rick Rubin collab." We were like, "We're doing what? That's amazing."
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A concrete example of unexpected cross-domain collaboration (music/creativity x AI/coding) that can inspire teams to pursue unconventional partnerships.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We've rebuilt it from the ground up with AI.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 3
quotes.context: Highlights a methodology of re-architecting a product end-to-end around AI rather than bolting it on incrementally.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: FileFeeds 2.0 allows non-technical teams to automate the process of transforming CSV and Excel files with just a simple prompt.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 3
quotes.context: Actionable product principle: use prompting to shift complex data transformation work from engineers to non-technical operators.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We support all of the trickiest file integrations, SFTP, S3, and even email.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 3
quotes.context: Concrete scope guidance on meeting users where they are by supporting real-world ingestion channels, including legacy ones like email.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Debugging these issues is often like finding a needle in a haystack.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 3
quotes.context: Memorable framing for why data-quality failures are disproportionately costly and hard to diagnose in production systems.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: OneSchema stops any bad data from entering your system and automatically validates your files, generating error reports with the exact issues in all bad files.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 3
quotes.context: Practical methodology: prevent downstream outages by validating at the boundary and producing precise, actionable error reports.

quotes.topic_title: How Mike was recruited to Anthropic
quotes.text: I was like, "Oh, how do I onboard myself? How do I get myself up to speed? How do I balance making sweeping changes versus understanding what's not broken about it overall?"
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A practical mental model for new leaders: explicitly balance rapid change with preserving what already works.

quotes.topic_title: How Mike was recruited to Anthropic
quotes.text: And looking back on a year, I think I made some changes too slowly. I think there was ways reorganizing product that I could have made a change earlier.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Actionable reflection that org/product leaders may need to move faster on structural changes once the diagnosis is clear.

quotes.topic_title: How Mike was recruited to Anthropic
quotes.text: And I think I didn't appreciate how much a couple of really key senior people can shape so much of product strategy.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Highlights the leverage of a small number of senior individuals on product direction—useful for hiring and org design.

quotes.topic_title: How Mike was recruited to Anthropic
quotes.text: Claude Code happened because Boris, who actually was a Boris Cherney, he was an Instagram engineer and one of our senior ICs there, we overlapped a bit, was started that project from scratch internal first and then we got it out and then shipped it.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Concrete example of an internal-to-external shipping path driven by a single senior IC, illustrating how new products can emerge.

quotes.topic_title: How Mike was recruited to Anthropic
quotes.text: But more than that we need a couple of almost founder type engineers that maybe connect back to our question on what skills are useful and how does product development change.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Contrarian hiring/prioritization takeaway: a few “founder-type” engineers can matter more than broad headcount growth.

quotes.topic_title: Why Artifact shut down and lessons learned
quotes.text: The way I put it's like 10 units of input in for one unit of output versus the other way around.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A simple ROI/traction heuristic for recognizing when a product/system lacks momentum despite strong execution.

quotes.topic_title: Why Artifact shut down and lessons learned
quotes.text: If we put blood and tears into the product and launch something we were proud of and metrics would barely move, the energy is not present in this product, in this system.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A diagnostic for product-market fit: great launches that don’t move metrics indicate missing underlying demand/virality.

quotes.topic_title: Why Artifact shut down and lessons learned
quotes.text: News was very personal. I can't tell you how many people would be like, "I love Artifact." I'm like, "Did you tell anybody about it?" And they're like, "I told one person," and it didn't have that kind of spread.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A counterintuitive growth lesson: even beloved products can stall if the category doesn’t naturally drive sharing.

quotes.topic_title: Why Artifact shut down and lessons learned
quotes.text: And the third one, which is an underappreciated one, is we started at mid-COVID, which meant that we were fully distributed and I think there were major shifts that we would've wanted to make both in the strategy and the product and the team. And it's really hard to do that if you are all fully remote.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: Operational insight: major pivots and team/strategy resets can be significantly harder to execute in fully remote mode.

quotes.topic_title: Why Artifact shut down and lessons learned
quotes.text: And most people, the universal reception, at least as I received it, was kudos for calling it when you saw it and not protracted doing this for a long time.
quotes.speaker: Mike Krieger
quotes.context: A practical shutdown principle: decisiveness can preserve reputation and free resources versus dragging out a low-traction effort.
